Weak links in modern power grids can lead to cascading failures from isolated incidents, making the scientific assessment of grid and transmission line vulnerability essential for preventing large-scale blackouts. This study conceptualizes transmission lines as functionally critical infrastructure and develops a four-dimensional vulnerability assessment framework encompassing Danger, Susceptibility, Resistance, and Recoverability, taking into account natural environmental conditions, human disturbances, grid operational states, and emergency response capabilities. Distinct from conventional classification methods that primarily rely on structural topology or subjective judgment, this study adopts a hazard index—based approach and introduces an objective weighting mechanism using the entropy method to quantitatively evaluate and classify indicators across the four dimensions. A case study of 500 kV transmission lines in Henan Province, China, reveals that the composite vulnerability index of the province's critical power infrastructure reaches 57.2, indicating a high level of vulnerability. Among the transmission towers, 19.8% are classified at the “Higher” level and 40.6% at the “High” level. Considerable variation in Recoverability among towers significantly influences the overall vulnerability assessment results. Moreover, the distribution of susceptibility to various hazards and accidents shows strong spatial and temporal heterogeneity, closely related to seasonal factors and tower locations. Based on these findings, targeted strategies are proposed from the perspectives of line inspection and differentiated management, providing technical support for enhancing power grid resilience and improving disaster response efficiency. Although the large-scale interconnection of power grids has achieved a wider range of optimal resource allocation, it has also reduced the safety and stability of the system, with widespread power outages cause: by localized failures occurring multiple times!. In recent years, earthquakes, rain, snow, freezing weather, rainstorms, typhoons, and other natural disasters around the world, as well as intentional or unintentiona external damage are threatening the stable operation of power grid transmission lines, even leading to large-scale power outages and other accidents, causing serious economic losses and social impact. For example, on July 13, 2019, a transformer fire caused a massive power outage in Midtown and the Upper West Side of Manhattan in New York City, U.S., with nearly 70,000 customers affected; the destruction of critical infrastructure an power disruptions in Yaan, Sichuan, China in 2013 and Wenchuan, Sichuan, China in 2008 due to earthquakes, and the massive power outage in southern China in 2008 due to severe weather caused by freezing rain an snow. In a comprehensive analysis of the above power emergencies, the initial cause is mostly the damage to the grid system by external factors, which leads to the unstable operation of the grid and thus causes serious socio-economic losses*->. Therefore, it is crucial to design a comprehensive vulnerability assessment metho to evaluate the safety risks of the grid in the context of natural disasters and external damage, and to develop targeted vulnerability reduction measures for the assessment results. The vulnerability analysis of the grid was first proposed by Petroianu et al. in 1974, but due to the small scale of the grid at that time, the vulnerability analysis of the grid did not receive sufficient attention. According to the different research contents, the research on vulnerability in the field of electric power can be divided into three categories. (1) Technical vulnerability assessment: Also known as electrical vulnerability, this method analyzes the power system’s structure and operational mode” based on the grid’s topology and system operating conditions. Depending on the research perspective, technical vulnerability in power grids can be classified into structural vulnerability'®, state vulnerability, and a comprehensive vulnerability assessment that integrates both perspectives!!-}3, Grid structural vulnerability assessment focuses on the tendency of a grid system to fail to maintain its topological integrity and normal operation after a certain unit or units exit due to external disturbances or failures in the system, and analyzes grid resilience from the perspective of the importance of a node or branch in the grid structure. For a particular grid, its network structure is unique, and therefore, structural vulnerability is a reflection of the inherent vulnerability of the grid'*!°, Complex network-based research methods are the mainstream approach to assessing the structural vulnerability of the grid'*!”. The grid state vulnerability assessment focuses on the tendency of the electrical parameters showing the system operating state to change abnormally and approach a critical value when a fault occurs in the system, thus making the grid unable to continue to provide services, and analyzing the grid’s ability to resist faults and disturbances from the operating state®. With the in-depth study of grid vulnerability, some scholars believe that the analysis model considering only structural vulnerability ignores the state parameters in operation, and the analysis method considering only state vulnerability ignores the importance of the unit in the grid structure, and both analysis and assessment methods have certain shortcomings'*!°. The assessment methods of grid vulnerability gradually develop from single attribute vulnerability assessment to integrated vulnerability assessment combining structural vulnerability and state vulnerability”.

McEntire (2001) states that vulnerability is determined by the extent to which the components of a disaster include risk, susceptibility, resistance, and recoverability. Risk and susceptibility are summarised as adverse factors, while resistance and recoverability are summarised as capacity factors*>*4. The current research on vulnerability in the field of electric power is divided into technical vulnerability, physical vulnerability and emergency vulnerability. To differentiate from technical vulnerability, this paper defines grid safety vulnerability as "the degree to which transmission lines (including towers) are vulnerable to loss of power system functions and adverse impacts on society due to insufficient structural strength or emergency recovery capabilities in the face of natural disasters and human damage”. This concept emphasizes the outstanding characteristics of four aspects of the safety vulnerability of power grid: (1) Danger: the possibility and severity of damage to the physical structure of power grid caused by natural disasters and man-made damage; (2) Susceptibility: the scope and degree of influence after the occurrence of power grid accident; (3) Resistance: the resistance of internal factors such as the structural strength of the power grid and the current operating state to external influences; (4) recoverability: the emergency repair and recovery ability of the power grid. Selecting the index elements according to the four aspects of “danger”, “susceptibility”, “resistance” and “recoverability” is the key to building the evaluation index system using the safety vulnerability model. Thus, we call it the DSRR model, which systematically reflects an analytical view of the relationship between environmental and human systems. The indicators in these four aspects each influence the grid’s safety vulnerability from the perspectives of both “offense” and “defense”. Specifically, danger and susceptibility are the attack factors of vulnerability and have a positive correlation with the safety vulnerability of the power grid. Danger represents the extent to which the power grid is affected by natural disasters and other external factors. Susceptibility represents the impact of the accident on society. The deeper the impact of the accident, the larger the scope of impact, the lower the social acceptance. It can be inferred that the higher the danger and susceptibility, the higher the safety vulnerability of the power grid. Resistance and recoverability are the defense factors of vulnerability and are negatively related to the safety vulnerability of the power grid. Resistance represents the ability of the transmission line itself to resist external influences, and recoverability represents the ability of emergency repair and recovery after the power grid accident. The higher the resistance and recoverability, the lower the vulnerability. The relationship between them is shown in Fig. 2.

In conclusion, this study establishes a comprehensive power grid safety vulnerability assessment framework incorporating four key dimensions: susceptibility, sensitivity, resistance, and resilience. By integrating the entropy weight method with GIS-based spatial analysis techniques, a multi-dimensional and spatially refined assessment approach is proposed. Taking the 500 kV transmission lines in Henan Province as a case study, the model effectively captures the differentiated vulnerability levels of transmission towers and identifies critical risk factors that impact grid stability. These findings provide a robust basis for implementing differentiated inspection protocols, targeted maintenance strategies, and focused mitigation of weak links in the power grid. Compared with existing vulnerability assessment approaches—many of which rely on structural topology or subjective weighting—this study demonstrates significant improvements in three aspects. First, it introduces a more objective weighting mechanism, where the entropy method reflects the inherent variability among indicators and eliminates the arbitrariness of expert judgment. Second, it constructs a systematically comprehensive indicator framework, integrating natural hazards, geographic conditions, socio-environmental contexts, and structural characteristics, thereby addressing the limitations of incomplete indicator coverage in prior models. Third, it enhances operational applicability, leveraging GIS tools to achieve spatial visualization and classification of vulnerable segments, thus improving the practicality and precision of risk identification. Accordingly, the proposed method outperforms conventional approaches in terms of theoretical rigor, evaluation accuracy, and practical relevance, offering a scalable and adaptable solution to support the enhancement of grid resilience and the modernization of safety management.
